daewoo

IU scientist find possible missing link
 
 http://www.indystar.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060325/LOCAL/603250494
 
 ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia -- Indiana University scientists working in northeastern Ethiopia said today they have discovered the skull of a small human ancestor that could be a missing link between the extinct Homo erectus and modern man.
 
 
 
The hominid cranium -- found in two pieces and believed to be between 500,000 and 250,000 years old -- "comes from a very significant period and is very close to the appearance of the anatomically modern human," said Sileshi Semaw, director of the Gona Paleoanthropological Research Project in Ethiopia.
 Archaeologists found the early human cranium five weeks ago at Gawis in Ethiopia's northeastern Afar region, Sileshi said.
 Sileshi, an Ethiopian paleoanthropologist based at Indiana University, said most fossil hominids are found in pieces but the near-complete skull -- a rare find -- provided a wealth of information.
 "The Gawis cranium provides us with the opportunity to look at the face of one of our ancestors," the archaeology project said in a statement. "Additionally, this fossil links us with the past by showing a face that is recognizably different and more primitive than ours."
 Homo erectus, which many believe was an ancestor of modern Homo sapiens, is thought to have died out 100,000 to 200,000 years ago.
 The cranium dates to a time about which little is known -- the transition from African Homo erectus to modern humans. The fossil record from Africa for this period is sparse and most of the specimens poorly dated, project archaeologists said.
 The face and cranium of the fossil are recognizably different from that of modern humans, but it bears unmistakable anatomical evidence that it belongs to the modern human's ancestry, Sileshi said.
 "The form of the face and the brain are among the best means for exploring the evolutionary path of humans and the Gawis cranium preserves both areas," according to the statement.
 Semaw is a research associate with IU's CRAFT Research Center. The research was supported by the Stone Age Institute, an independent, nonprofit center based north of Bloomington that is an outgrowth of the CRAFT Research Center.
 The Stone Age Institute researches human origins and the development of technology.

 
 I am primarily interested in seeing how the creationists wriggle around this one. It would seem that if the early analysis of this is correct, the creationist argument is essentially dead once and for all.

 Well, let's see.

 Sadly, past experience suggests that creationists can wriggle on indefinitely.

It would seem that if the early analysis of this is correct, the creationist argument is essentially dead once and for all.
I doubt it. They know the TROOTH and will refuse to be confused by facts.
 
6. So where's the missing link between the new fossil and us? Huh? Huh?
How about the Herto skulls? Herto skulls (Homo sapiens idaltu)
 
 So it seems that the gap between 500,000 years and 100,000 years is being filled. Now we have Homo erectus, H. ergaster, H. antecessor, Homo heidelbergensis (archaic H. sapiens), H. ??? (Gawis, Afar, Ethiopia), H. sapiens idaltu, H. sapiens sapiens.
 
 This seems to lend even more support to the Out of Africa II hypothesis. H. heidelbergensis has been found in Africa, Spain, and Europe and is believed to be ancestral to H. neanderthalensis. Late H. heidelbergensis are very much like early Neandertal fossils. But H. heidelbergensis in Africa seems to have led to H. sapiens through the above lineage, followed by migration through the Levant into Europe.
 
 Of course, there is the very real (probable) possibility that I am jumping the gun a bit on this. I hate that "missing link" press gush.

I hate that "missing link" press gush.

What's more, no matter how many intermediate forms you find (and all creationists know that no truly intermediate fossils exist - Kent Hovind et al tell them so) they will always demand intermediates between your intermediates, and declare evolution busted if they can't be produced.
Alan Ryan

You and me both. Sadly, creationists are addicted to the notion, and no amount of biological explanation will wean them off it.  Hasn't developments in molecular biology made the fossil record redundant to the study of our evolutionary past?
johnhanks

Hasn't developments in molecular biology made the fossil record redundant to the study of our evolutionary past?

 
 Not really. Developments in molecular biology can measure (or at least estimate) divergence times between ourselves and other extant species, assuming constant mutation rates. Only the fossil record can trace the actual pathways that evolution took after those divergence dates. Unfortunately, most fossils contain little or no original DNA or protein, and are not susceptible to molecular analysis.
 
 Needless to say, disagreements between the calculations of molecular biologists and the findings of palaeontologists have been exploited to the full by creationists. And who can blame them? If I had a handful of nothing in a poker game, I'd be looking to unsettle my opponents too.
Alan Ryan

Only the fossil record can trace the actual pathways that evolution took after those divergence dates.  I've just traced what was on my mind when I asked the question: Dawkins in his "Ancestor's Tale" (which I finished recently), says, "that even if every fossil was 'magicked away', the comparative study of modern organisms, of how their patterns of resemblances, especially of genetic sequences, are distributed among species would still demonstrate, beyond all doubt, that our history is evolutionary and that all living creatures are cousins. Fossils are a bonus". 
 
 I interpreted this to suggest creationist demands that the 'fossil gaps' be filled are really quite superfluous.

 When I read Edmund Gosse's book "Father and Son", I was astonished to learn that Gosse's father (who was a professional naturalist) categorically denied that fossils were evidence supporting the theory of evolution.

When I read Edmund Gosse's book "Father and Son", I was astonished to learn that Gosse's father (who was a professional naturalist) categorically denied that fossils were evidence supporting the theory of evolution. 
 
 He said that God had deliberately put fossils in the earth as a 'challenge' to believers in the Christian faith !!!!

 
 A lot of my students start with the misapprehension that the existence of fossils per se is held up as evidence for evolution. It is not, of course - it is merely evidence that these organisms once existed, not that they evolved from or into anything else. Fossil series are a different matter, and can provide powerful evidence as long as they are not misrepresented. When they are (as in the notorious 'ascent of man' diagrams) they simply provide ammunition for creationists.
 
 
You know the general idea - the more absurd the belief, the more religious 'merit' there is in believing it.

Or maybe he never even existed to begin with. Here's something interesting that I found while looking for further information about the Gawis skull. Since it hasn't been published yet, there is little further except the preliminary remarks posted heres. However, I was looking at the Homo sapiens idaltu skulls (BOU-VP-16/1, BOU-VP-16/2, BOU-VP-16/5) from Herto (at Talk Origins) and noticed this interesting bit at the bottom of the page.
 
Answers in Genesis argues, quite reasonably, that these fossils are so similar to modern humans that they don't constitute any problem for creationists - or, at least, to their own position. Reasons To Believe, an old-earth creationist ministry founded by Hugh Ross, takes the more surprising position that these fossils are of soulless animals that merely look like humans, and has accused AIG of "factual errors and distortions", to which AIG has responded energetically. RTB's position seems untenable to me: it's hard to see how anyone can credibly claim that fossils so remarkably similar to modern humans are animals. RTB appears to have a strategy that by definition excludes any possibility of transitional fossils: if scientists put a fossil in anything other than Homo sapiens sapiens, it is "not a modern human" and hence is an animal (no matter how trivial the differences); if they do put it in H. sapiens sapiens, of course, it's also not evidence for human evolution. Heads I win, tails you lose.
I found it funny to see the two creationist sites battling about this. They both claim to base their opinion on the Bible, one claiming that the Herto skulls are just humans and the other claiming that they are animals. The response to RTB by AIG (Wieland) reproduces the exchange of communications between AIG and RTB. I found it quite humorous.
DamEtel

... it's hard to see how anyone can credibly claim that fossils so remarkably similar to modern humans are animals. 

 
 Modern humans are animals.
 
 Sorry to distract from the main point of that last post, which is quite valid, and this distraction is kind of a nit pick, but...
 
 Every time a non-theistic source makes the mistake of saying or implying that we humans are not animals, the more convinced religious people become that we are not. And that puts a supposed barrier between humans and animals, which in turn makes it "impossible" for us to be the result of an evolutionary process.
 
 Scientists have a term for non-human animals ... it is, well, non-human animals! Or, NHAs for short.
pandion

Modern humans are animals.
Point taken. Maybe that idea should be communicated to Jim Foley at Talk Origins.
 
Sorry to distract from the main point of that last post, which is quite valid, and this distraction is kind of a nit pick, but...
 
 Every time a non-theistic source makes the mistake of saying or implying that we humans are not animals, the more convinced religious people become that we are not. And that puts a supposed barrier between humans and animals, which in turn makes it "impossible" for us to be the result of an evolutionary process.
But I think that Foley's words were in response to the view of the creationists at RTB - the Herto fossils are of animals, not humans. Perhaps he should have said, "...just animals..." as opposed to "...human animals..."
 
 On another board a creationist asked me to clarify some remarks I has made about Neandertals. The creationist asked if Neandertals were human. I said that yes they were, but not modern humans. He responded with, "Were neanderthals human or were they a differant species?" My answer was that Neandertals were a different species of human.
johnhanks

On another board a creationist asked me to clarify some remarks I has made about Neandertals. The creationist asked if Neandertals were human. I said that yes they were, but not modern humans. He responded with, "Were neanderthals human or were they a differant species?" My answer was that Neandertals were a different species of human.

 
 Biologists know that species don't have rigid boundaries. Are Drosophila willistoni willistoni and D. willistoni quechua the same species, even though crosses between them produce sterile male offspring? If they are, at what stage in their divergence will they become different species? If we reify the abstract concept 'species', we come down to quibbling over semantics.
 
 Creationists like the one you refer to cannot handle this idea at all. For them species are closed boxes with sharply defined walls, and any individual must be either in one box or another. Last I heard, Neandertals were conventionally regarded as a subspecies of sapiens. We can never know, sadly, whether we and they would have been interfertile (though that hasn't stopped a lot of people from speculating).
 
 As a postscript, I'd suggest that this same lack of understanding about species and speciation underlies the frequent misguided demands from creationists (notably easyrider in the Religion forum) that we 'name the Missing Link'. They seem to picture human evolution as a kind of saltatory process, jumping from one discrete, clearly defined species to another, rather than as a continuum involving many diverging (and merging) populations.
Ripskar

The "Missing Link" refers to the last common ancestor linking the homonids and chimps/bonobos (aprox; 5-7 mya).
 There are plenty of fossils between Homo erectus and Homo sapiens though the common ancestor remains elusive (and will probably remain so until the political[military] situation in Africa stabilises enough for paleontological digs to opperate freely.) don't expect the creationist crowd to see sense even when a specimin is identified.
 These people don't recognise Lucy as an ancestor, there can be no understanding, no compromise, no forgiveness. This is survival of fittest and they are unwilling to adapt, thus they doom themselves to inevitable extinction.

This is survival of fittest and they are unwilling to adapt, thus they [Creationists] doom themselves to inevitable extinction.

 
 Being the slight majority in America (IIRC), Creationists don't have to change: they already are "well adapted" to life in this country, as sad as that is. 
 
 And unfortunately for freethinkers, survival of the fittest doesn't mean survival of the most rational nor of the most educated. There's no guarantee that rational thought and reasoning can or will always overcome age-old superstition and faith in the supernatural.
 
 Your optimism sounds a lot like Voltaire's pronouncement back in the late 1700s that in 100 years or so Christianity would be eliminated and replaced by more enlightened views. Sadly, that didn't happen here in America.

The "Missing Link" refers to the last common ancestor linking the homonids and chimps/bonobos (aprox; 5-7 mya).
That may be what you mean by "missing link," but that's not what most creationists mean by it. Most creationists actually think that the missing link would be between modern humans and some ape ancestor.
 
 By the way, chimps are hominids, i.e., members of the family Hominidae. The family includes all of the great apes; humans, chimps, gorillas, and orangutans.
johnhanks

By the way, chimps are hominids, i.e., members of the family Hominidae. The family includes all of the great apes; humans, chimps, gorillas, and orangutans.

 
 Is this now official? I'd heard it proposed, but as far as I was aware the great apes were still Pongidae. Does the latter now include only gibbons and siamangs?
pandion

Is this now official? I'd heard it proposed, but as far as I was aware the great apes were still Pongidae. Does the latter now include only gibbons and siamangs?
It has come to be general usage in the last several years. I first became familiar with it from two paleoanthropologists. I thought that I might as well get used to it now before I get too old to learn anything new.
 
 The gibbons and siamangs are in the family Hylobatidae.
 
 Try this. Go to the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology Animal Diversity web site and do a search on Pongidae. Surprising, no?
 
 Order Primates remain the same - the lemurs, monkeys, and apes.
 Superfamily Hominoidea - the apes with two famililes, Hylobatidae and Hominidae.
 Family Hylobatidae - the lesser apes (gibbons and siamangs)
 Family Hominidae - the great apes and ancestors.
 Subfamily Homininae - chimps, gorillas, humans and ancestors
 Subfamily Ponginae - the orangutans.
 Tribe Hominini - chimps and humans and ancestors.
Ripskar

 And unfortunately for freethinkers, survival of the fittest doesn't mean survival of the most rational nor of the most educated. There's no guarantee that rational thought and reasoning can or will always overcome age-old superstition and faith in the supernatural.
 
 Your optimism sounds a lot like Voltaire's pronouncement back in the late 1700s that in 100 years or so Christianity would be eliminated and replaced by more enlightened views. Sadly, that didn't happen here in America.

 
 Actually I have a pessimistic view, it is not the spread of rationality etc. that dooms creationism (And definately not Christianity etc.).
 Creationism will most likely fall to presure form the liberal wing of the 
 church(es).
 As you are aware they don't bother to listen to us, but the situation is not static, they will become more isolated and more like the Flat Earth Society as time goes on.
 The ultimate irony is that the greatest threat to creationism comes from Christians, their own superstitions are far more effective weapons than rational argument.
 The US is odd case in many ways but preachers from elsewhere, and therefore ideas form elsewhere within Christainity must permeate. 
 That takes time of course and tends to be patchy by its nature but it is happening. Religious thought is regularly outpaced by glacial flow but as we've seen elsewhere notions are not permanent.

It has come to be general usage in the last several years...

 
 Thank you. I should have remembered the gibbons were Hylobatidae. I'm grateful to be updated on the rest.
pandion

Tribe Hominini - chimps and humans and ancestors.
Of course, this is a rather new "trend" in taxonomy. In the older system the chimpanzees were in the tribe Panini. So the lumping has happened on more than one level. The trend is now to lump the Pongidae into the Hominidae and then further down the classification to lump the Panini into the Hominini.
 
 These changes are mostly driven by DNA studies that have revealed that these organisms are more closely related than previously thought. However, the classifications still haven't stabilized to the point that every one agrees. I found that it was easy to find multiple versions of primate taxonomy. Some include Pan in Hominini, others don't, making Hominini include just humans and ancestors since our split from the chimp (Pan) lineage. In that system, chimps are in the subfamily Homininae, but still in the tribe Panini.
 
 Like I said before, I hope this all settles down before I'm too old to learn something new.
